contextId.occurrenceNote: The purpose of this question is to have Esther think deeply about her role in this situation. Alternate translation: "Who knows, perhaps it was for just for a time like this that you were made queen." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Who knows whether you have come to this royal position for such a time as this?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed as a statement. "Surely there is no one whom the king would take pleasure in honoring more than me!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Whom would the king take pleasure in honoring more than me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king uses this question to show his shock and anger at what Haman was doing. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "He even dares to attack the queen in my presence and in my own house!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will he assault the queen in my presence in my own house?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Esther used these questions to show that that she would be extremely sad if her people were to be destroyed. Alternate translation: "I cannot bear to see disaster fall on the Jews. I cannot endure watching my relatives be killed." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: For how could I bear to see disaster fall on my people? How could I endure watching the destruction of my relatives?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king uses this question to show that he believes that the Jews must have also killed many people in the other provinces. Alternate translation: "What they must have done in the rest of the king's provinces!" or "They must have killed many more in the rest of the king's provinces!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What then have they done in the rest of the king's provinces?
